utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hi. I'm Greg Gutfeld with Kimberly Guilfoyle, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, and a pea bob is her sleeping bag, Dana Perino -- "The Five."

utterances.speaker: Donald Trump is at Davos. I know
utterances.utterance: What is Davos, you ask? It's the home of the World Economic Forum where world leaders and business executives drink expensive wine, eat fancy meat and throw up in hot tubs. And also tell us what's wrong with us. I was going to go but my Gulfstream has been acting up and my manservant then has an infected uvula. But these elites won't be giving Trump a warm welcome at all and he's already pissed off at cliffs. Take a look at that. An angry mountain. Swiss activists did that. Pretty funny that there's activists in Switzerland. Please, their biggest problem is being confused for Sweden.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But it's not like Donald Trump cares. In fact, the angrier they get, the more his economic policies stand out. But before the Euros go full anti-Trump, maybe look at us first. Our economy is on fire, so much so that Swiss could warm their hands on it. It's cause and effect. Because of the lower corporate tax, now even Starbucks -- Starbucks -- is giving workers raises worth millions. It's funny. A company raises its wages and Democrats go silent. I guess they just want the government to make those decisions. And now, Fiat Chrysler says the U.S. workers -- its U.S. workers will receive two grand in bonuses. This is great news for you and bad news for all those vulnerable Democrats up for reelection who didn't back the bill, which means they can't take any credit. All they can hope for is a reversal of fortunes. That's a sad place to be, rooting for bad news so you might win. I want to point out that many of us are wearing burgundy today. No reason why. It just happens.

utterances.speaker: KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It just happens.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It's interesting, isn't it?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Not a secret society.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, secret society of burgundy. And so, Dana.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I bet you have a theory about what's going down. His first day in Davos, and he's doing great.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, indeed, he is. And it looked to me like he was having a good time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, he was.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, every time he's gone overseas, it's like, oh, actually, you know what? He has friends. He's making friends around the world, making relationships. This is actually, I think, one of the things that I imagine a Trump presidency would bring. So, he's a disruptor.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: This is my theory, I was going to say, if Steve Bannon were still in the White House and advising the president, I think this visit would look very different.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The tone and tenor of it would be different. The speech would be different. Instead, what he's able to do there is go and say, hey, I'm the head coach of capitalism, and the world economy is going well. The United States is even kicking it into higher gear. So let's all work together. Let's do more. What all can we do here? I get the America First, not America alone type of thing. It's not my favorite rhetoric. But on the other side, I think that the leaders who are there -- there's some world leaders there but there's also business leaders. Reality has set in. For a long time they thought, well, President Trump really doesn't want to be president or he doesn't really want to run again. And now they're starting to realize after the first year that he governs very differently than he campaigns, and that they're figuring out a way to work with him, and today there was a roundtable that he did with some business leaders and all of them were like, we've got to invest in the United States and we're planning to increase that. And pretty soon, all of these companies -- there's going to be so many companies in America that are announcing bonuses that if you're the outlier and you have not announced bonuses, that will become something.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Not bonuses for people like you, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Oh, what's that supposed to mean?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You're under contract.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's easier to say like which companies haven't gone ahead and done -- maybe, companies are still thinking about it because you hear news about it every day.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's such a good point. Jesse, it's like a weird version -- a combination of trickle-down economics and peer pressure. You start watching everybody -- I mean, how can you not deny this cause and effect. It's happening.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, it's not trickle-down economics. It's more of like a flood.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And it's not coming from the top down. It's broad base and growing out.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Flash flood.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, flash flood, water's world. It's not just a $1,000 bonuses. Some of it is profit sharing checks. They're getting checks $5,000, they're reinvesting in America.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But also, they lowered the prices of -- the energy costs and several different utilities across the country.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right. And some companies are even throwing money into college funds for the workers and things like that. So, it's going to be very difficult for the Democrats to run against winning. I don't see how they do it. How can you deny your 401(K) exploding? How can you deny tax cuts?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They're like climate deniers. There winning deniers. It's so easy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's a great line.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's so easy and you could see it coming from a mile away, yet not one Democrat voted for the corporate tax cut, and the deregulation is responsible to. The only way they're going to have to run against him is just go super negative and try to bring out women, blacks and Latinos, which don't usually turn out in the midterms. It's not a sure thing winning back the house.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm stealing winning deniers for my show on Saturday. I wrote it down. All right. So Juan, I want to play a sought from another network. I know. But you have to help these people out because nobody's watching. This is their take on Trump and Davos.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: And we should point out one other thing, the chair people of Davos this year, this year there are seven, I believe all of them are women. When I look at President Trump right there, I mentioned, -- was with him, Jared Kushner, Gary Cohn, Rex Tillerson. He's flanked almost entirely -- well, there's one, by white guys.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So Juan, obviously, they have race on the brain over at MSNBC, nothing but white men. Clearly, this is a racist gathering. It must be stop. This is almost an alt-right event.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yeah, it could be, except it's overseas, right? No, I mean, you know, I think the economy is going great. I think everybody is excited. It's wonderful. But if you're saying that this is somehow good news that he's at Davos bragging about the American economy, let me tell you, there're several economies overseas that are doing even better.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Like what?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, there're so many, but China is obviously doing much better. Then you go into Europe.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because workers get paid pennies over there.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, OK, all right, so now we're making excuses again.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's reality. It's like slave labor.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, a minute ago you're saying the American economy is just booming. It's never been like this. Second thing to say is a majority of Americans credit President Obama, not President Trump, with response.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Are they really Americans?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, I see. Anybody who disagreed with Trump is not an American. Fake news, fake news.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Can I finish? And then, this morning papers have Republicans rebelling against Trump because he's raising tariffs.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . that are raising prices and people are saying don't do it. And then, don't forget, the farmers and others are still lobbying.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They're not happy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . against the idea that he wants to break apart and after. Break apart trade deals.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is what makes Republicans honest because -- I don't want a protectionist leader. I have a theory he's playing tough with these deals, but I don't think he's protectionist.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I'm just saying, you know, there's a lot more to this story about the economy and the idea that he can run on the economy, obviously, if most Americans think the economy is booming, doing great, but they don't credit Donald Trump. That's not good news for Republicans.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Let's see how long they're able to try to create an alternate reality. Alternative facts there and not accept that Donald Trump has actually done quite a bit here. I mean, look, he's got a housing rebound. The economy is accelerating. Job numbers up, infrastructure involvement up. And there's a lot of positive things happening here that you credit President Trump, including the corporate tax cuts. So, all of this is actually positioning not only the president but Republicans have something to work with in terms of these midterm races. So, he's in a very good position. He's there in Davos. It's fantastic that the president is participating and showing up there. Some of the people are quite upset that he's taking the press away from them. But he has wins on his side. And he's coming strong out of this whole battle with Schumer and DACA. So, you know, right now, this is a very positive positioning for the president.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what I think, is the fact is, that what you see at Davos, Kimberly, is people who are saying, I think the theme of the whole thing is fractured world, but we have a shared future in terms of a global economy. And so, they are going ahead in terms of trade deals. They're going ahead in terms of trying to work together multilaterally. Meanwhile, Trump is there saying, oh, no, this is about bilateral agreements with the United States, and he's saying we are putting the U.S. first and we are about isolationism, if not protectionism. That is not a happy message.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know what amuses me, when the left says Trump was going to crash the economy. Then the economy accelerates and they say Obama gets credit for it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: How about the American people say that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: When people get a $1,000 bonus check in January 2018, how is that Obama's?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: By the way, I think the latest polls are 40 percent believe the economy is better has to do with Trump and the others one are split. So there's no majority of Americans.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And for Republicans and President Trump, they're definitely improving just even in the last four weeks.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And part of that is just all the good headlines. But I've got a couple points. One is that for Democrats who didn't vote for these tax cuts and tax reform, this could have been theirs. President Obama did want to cut the corporate tax rate to 27. The corporations were excited about that. But he wouldn't budge on individual rates because he wanted to increase taxes on the ridge. So, all of this could have been theirs. And the companies that have announced bonuses, imagine what they would have done.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, God.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: . to bend over backwards to try to help. So there's a missed opportunity. The other thing that works in conservatives favor is you see some companies pushing to $15 an hour. That was done without the government telling them they had to.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, that is another way for conservatives to say that the market works. The last thing I would say that is good for the president to do is as he meets with these other world leaders, Theresa May, Macron, and also, Kagame of Rwanda, there's going to come a time when he will have to ask one of these world leaders for a favor or for help and it will be politically unpopular in their country for them to do it, but if he has personal relationships with them, it's more likely they'll be willing to pony up.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's a salesman. You know, one last thing, Switzerland, my belief that they should not be allowed to have activists. If they are neutral -- No, they're neutral, they're not allowed to play. That's like dealing yourself at a blackjack table without any chips. You know what I'm saying? If you're neutral, you can't protest, how about that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Neutral as a military power.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know. I don't read a lot.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Switzerland or Sweden?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I get them confused.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: One of them yodel. One of them yodel, right? The Swiss yodel and Swedes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Fish.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Fish? They fish. Don't do it at the same time, kids.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. I think Donald Trump is going to come back with a few Norwegians. I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Will President Trump be meeting with Mueller soon? He wants to testify other oath and he's looking forward to it, next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: President Trump has always said there was no collusion with the Russians and he's ready to talk to Robert Mueller to put an end to the investigation.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Are you going to talk to Mueller?

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: I'm looking forward to it, actually.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: There's been no collusion, whatsoever. There's no obstruction, whatsoever. And I'm looking forward to it.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Do you have date set?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: I don't know. I guess they're talking about two or three weeks, but I would love to do it. Again, I have to say, subject to my lawyers and all of that, but I have to do it.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: Would you do it under oath, Mr. President?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: I would do it under oath.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Some top legal analysts, though, think it might not be the best idea for Mr. Trump.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: This is an extremely dangerous situation to allow the president to get in because he does not know and cannot know as much about the case as Bob Mueller and his fellow interrogators will know. And he might very well say things which would lead them to other areas of investigation.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: It leaves me worrying that what's going to happen is that this investigation will end not with a bang but a whimper. The great worry is that because he doesn't have anything really substantial, he may go after obstruction of justice which would create a constitutional crisis.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Kimberly, it is very clear that it would not be a good idea for the president of the United States to go sit down with Robert Mueller and answer questions under oath.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK, so says top legal analyst, Watters' world.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you concur?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I concur, consul. Yes, I think it would be a very bad idea. I don't think he should offer to give testimony. And I think the problem is when you do something like this it's very -- you can open up other areas and then they start going there. And also, inconsistent statements, problems like that, then they try to say OK, but you lied to investigators. They tried to then impeach you with some prior statement or get someone else to contradict you. So that's why you see his attorneys pushing back on it. End up saying, OK, wait a second. Let's see.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Ty Cobb cleaned that up pretty quickly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Under advise of council.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The cleanup hitter came in. Juan, he's probably just being a little cocky, wants to show that his confident, and doesn't have anything to hide. And maybe just went a little too far. You don't think he really wants to go in there and go toe to toe with Mueller, do you?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He's a very confident man, isn't he?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, there we go. I mean, he probably thinks he can sell ice cubes to Eskimos.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He can.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You assuming they like ice cubes because they're Eskimos?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No. Gin and tonic.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Gin and Tonic?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Where do you think the president, Juan, would be the most nervous or would get the most nervous answering questions from Robert Mueller? Where do you think he has the most exposure?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, he's got so much exposure. Well, he starts asking him about things like, well, Michael Flynn or the firing of Jim Comey. But let's just go with collusion for the moment. What about Michael Flynn? What about the fact that Flynn lied about contacts with the Russians? What about your son having meetings with the Russian lawyer, what about you asking the Russians to hack Hillary Clinton? I can go on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, the what about? OK. I think the president might be able to respond pretty effectively to the what about question. Dana, you went through this when the special counsel -- you didn't personally.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I did not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That has to be, probably, the most frightening thing in the world.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: As I recall, I don't remember precisely. I don't think there was ever a request to talk to President Bush about any of that. I don't remember that. Cheney, they did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Can the president get out of having.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I actually wanted to ask Kimberly that. I mean, I wouldn't volunteer an interview but can he be compelled to talk? I mean, it might not entirely be his choice.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right. This is what I like about what they suggested because you don't want to look like you have something to hide, that you're afraid, you're not being forthright because the perception of that could be worse, perhaps, than even him coming forward. What I like is a carefully tailored affidavit under penalty of perjury, sworn, that his attorneys with him, the system of council, prepared to show that he is.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Because he might not have a choice, right?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: . by cooperating, right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But I also think that what he was doing yesterday was, it's not, maybe -- I think he's thinking three steps ahead. I don't necessarily think it's confidence. I think it is setting himself up to say, look, you heard me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I wanted to.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I wanted to. You heard me. I wanted to talk to them but it was the lawyers. My lawyers said no, so I've got to listen to my lawyers. Surely you can understand that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think you're probably right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Though there's the P.R. strategy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think you're right. Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think he's probably really good at depositions.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He's got experienced?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I mean deposition for him is like a dental appointment.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Like a Tuesday.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's Tuesday. But, he's kind of like -- imagine like a rock climbing wall that looks really easy and then you get there and it just goes flat. I think that's what Trump is like when he gets into a legal.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Like Spider-man.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There's no way to get on -- find a place because he'll be just like, I don't know, I don't know this, I don't know that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Opposite of how he usually is.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's why I think it's probably going to be hard for people to say, well, he didn't -- he wouldn't have known that obstruction of justice was wrong. But then he has all this experience, so I don't know if that's going to wash.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But isn't obstruction of justice -- does it actually have to stop the investigation? And the investigation has still went on.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But he never impeded the investigation.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He tried.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But when he fired Mueller he didn't imped it -- or Comey.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Even this week, with the question that he put -- I guess it was to McCabe about, you know, who'd you vote for? I mean, these things are like indicating that he wants the investigation to go a certain way and not another way. He wants politics.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It seems to me the lawyers though for Trump right now are trying to use leverage, and I think Trump is part of this to say maybe we would agree to a written question and we'll give you written answers as opposed - - they don't want him before a grand jury.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Greg, you weren't here yesterday when the texts came out? Have you anything to say about the texts?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Apparently there's a lost and found. Who knew? I mean, where did they find them? Under the pillow where you lose your remote? This is insane. But you know what? They wouldn't have found them. They wouldn't have found them if there wasn't pressure from certain people to.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't think that's true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Definitely.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But the guy that found them is the inspector general who doesn't have a dog in the fight. They found them and like -- basically like 30 minutes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, we do want to see these text. Demented Dr. Larry Nassar will now rot in jail for the rest of his life. The gymnasts he victimized want many more held accountable, up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: One chapter closed yesterday in the U.S. gymnastic sexual abuse scandal, but there is more justice to be served for Larry Nassar's crimes. Many people in power knew about the abuse and did nothing to stop it. The victims want to make sure they too are held accountable and that this never happens again.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: The USA gymnastics is really an organization that's rotting from the inside out. They created a culture of physical, psychological and mental abuse. But they also had a policy of not reporting sexual predators. When you have a culture that is abusive and then you have a policy of not reporting sexual abuse, you have created the perfect dynamic for a predator to be able to flourish.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: It was a combination of the wrong people being in charge and neglecting things that needed to be done legally and didn't do them. One hundred and ten percent shouldn't have never met this man -- in my life. Something went wrong.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: We need to hold these organizations accountable. USA gymnastics, United States Olympic Committee, MSU, they need an independent investigation. This is bigger than Larry Nassar.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Hours after Nassar's sentencing, the president of MSU did step down. Not much accountability in Lou Anna Simon statement though. Listen, she said, as tragedies are politicized, blame is inevitable. As president, it's only natural that I am the focus of this anger. I understand. Therefore, I am tendering my resignation. Kimberly, is there -- are there more legal acts to be taken against people who might have known about this and didn't do anything?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yeah, potentially, I mean, certainly there will be civil lawsuits as well that can abound from this. First you usually see a criminal prosecution, you know, the proceeds of civil litigation or some kind of class action could come forward to suspending because there's certainly quite a large number of young girls who were victimized. Then it comes down to these organizations and them being held accountable. What did people know? When do they know it? It does really remind me of Penn State, and you think about it in terms of these abuses, like was someone told? Did they not document it? Did they allow it to continue? So, there's an ability there for them to bring something forward to say, you know, you had a duty to protect and to keep us safe, and yet you put us in a very vulnerable and dangerous, you know, position where we were victimized. And I think that the young women were quite articulate in terms of explaining their position and their vulnerability and using their voice to say that there should be more of a thorough independent investigation to these entities.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Kimberly brought up what happened in the Sandusky trial. Remember, all the people there said, you know, never again. And I think it's interesting how human beings, we continue to learn these lessons over and over again, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, it's so sad and, you know, in reading and listening to the young women talk about it, it was shocking to me. They said that they were told that it was required that they allow this man to come into their hotel rooms, their dorm rooms anytime of night. No nurse in attendance and no restrictions on what he was doing. And they were told this is what you need to do. If you don't do it, you're going to be punished and you will be penalized in terms of participating with the team. So, what's interesting to me is the statement coming from the president of Michigan State because she's basically saying something that sound reasonable on his face, which is she's the president of a huge, important university, and how was she to know what some miscreant doctor is doing? But on the other hand, you realize "The Indianapolis Star" broke the story. Other people have been involved, and it was a very slow response. And I can -- I would think that she should have known at that point something is wrong here. And we've got to protect children. The same thing with the people who are on USA Gymnastics. I just think they become blind, in terms of pursuing competition, to protecting children.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's really remarkable how -- Kimberly said, how articulate they were, saying during the sound bite, they're...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Poised.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: ... poised. They're so mature. And they were going through all of this inner turmoil, Jesse, and yet, they were able to perform and be just amazing athletes and students, as well.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right, but I don't think USA Gymnastics thought of them as athletes. I thought they probably thought of them as just gold medal factories. I don't think they saw them as human beings. There's red flags everywhere. This is the biggest sports scandal in history. Juan touched on it a little bit. I'm reading some of this stuff. The doctor never wore gloves. He's walking around not wearing gloves, alone in hotel rooms. He was the first call they were supposed to make at nighttime. He's isolating them in mandatory camps across the country where they're cutting off communication with their parents, their agents and their lawyers. And the minute you complain, you're told you're not on the team anymore? I mean, it sounds like you're putting a serial pedophile in charge of young girls for decades, and no one saw anything abnormal about it. This is not just Penn-State-level scandal. This is Catholic Church level scandal. And I think Congress needs to get involved.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think that they went back. I think that there was a call for at least a hearing and maybe more. Greg, Juan brings up "The Indianapolis Star." They -- investigative journalists were the ones that were the initial instigators that led to this lawsuit.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Which meant that this stuff was probably percolating, just like the Harvey Weinstein stuff. It was percolating. People knew or heard things and then somebody finally said, "I'm going to go follow it up." I think when you're seeing a lot of unhappiness after this, after the sentencing, because we realize there's actually no adequate punishment to fit the crime. There is no actual -- there's no punishment. I mean, I suppose you could skin him alive, but I don't know if we're allowed to do that.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK, ISIS.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, but I mean -- no. You would -- really, is skinning alive really that bad with this? But I mean, people who argue against the death penalty always say that living in prison with the guilt of what you've done is actually worse than death. Every day -- and it's like, I disagree. I think people -- you'd be surprised what people can live with and adapt to. Human beings, animals evolved to their surroundings. He will figure out a way to live, unless, you know, he decides not to live because it's so unbearable, if people make it unbearable.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Can I ask Greg a question?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Sure.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What do you think of this judge? Because I worry about the judge. I think she went a little -- I mean, you know, Larry Nassar should go to jail, but boy, she put on a show. Now, is it cathartic for the women involved? Is that what this was about? Or does she think that, because he's a bad guy, she can use the power of her standing to just beat the living daylights out of him?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: We talked about this yesterday.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, I -- it's interesting, because the case is so heinous. That I do -- I had a tinge of misgivings about some of the high drama, but if there was a case that can forgive high drama, it's this one. If it were a different case where it was like Juan Williams, you know, dealing with parking tickets or something like that that and somebody is, like, going "You work for FOX News. You're a terrible person." That's -- because there are cameras in the courtroom, and people get hyper dramatic. In this case, I can see -- I found it to be highly dramatic, but in this kind of case, it's almost like so what?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Let me -- let me give Kimberly the last word. Because one of the things -- I listened to the daily podcast this morning, and they had interviewed a few of these girls about what it was like to confront him. And they said how cathartic it was, how they felt like a burden had been lifted off of their shoulders and that she gave them encouragement. And, you know, victims' impact statements are part of...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The Supreme Court ruled...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: ... that this is allowed.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It's permissible, and there's plenty of evidence to document that it is something that is very healing. It's important for them to have their voice. We talked about this yesterday. In so many of the cases that I've prosecuted for sexual assault and domestic violence, crimes against women and children, the one thing that they say is to be able to be -- have their day in court and stand and face the person that has committed heinous crimes against them, is very empowering. And very helpful for them moving forward in their lives. The judge was, like, well within her rights to do what she did.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK. John Kerry is reportedly considering another run for the White House. The 2020 buzz ahead.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: John Kerry's White House bid didn't go so well for him in 2004, but now there's word he may try again in 2020, this time to take on President Trump. There's also a report floating around overseas that the former secretary of state has tried to undermine the president's Mideast peace efforts, advising Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas not to yield to President Trump's demands. But that report is unconfirmed. So Dana, where do you go with this? What do you think?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I loved to see a little rematch of '04. Sounds good here.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Rematch?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, remember, John Kerry ran against President George W. Bush in '04.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't think George W. can run again.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, no, I just mean, like, watching John Kerry run again would be interesting. I have to ask my friend Michael Meehan what he thinks. He was chief of staff to the campaign, and I'm -- look, Americans usually give a president a second term. That is just historically what we do. It is very rare for a president to lose reelection. And I guess Democrats probably think that if they had a chance that this would be their time, but I don't know. I don't think that -- I don't think Democrats want to go backwards. I think they want to look for somebody new, and John Kerry is not going to fit that bill. Plus, I have heard that President Obama has said that, if Joe Biden wants to run, he will have his full support. So if you're going to try to run without Obama's support, that's going to be tough.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Kimberly, what do you think about the report that he's telling leaders of the Palestinians, "Don't worry."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Terrible.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: "Trump will be gone in a year."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Terrible. I'm sorry. Go ahead. That's the worst.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I mean, that's not going to help him at all.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's not going to help the Palestinians either.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It's not going to help the Palestinians, not helping Kerry.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Idiotic. Traitorous.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Outrageous, is what it is. But listen to me, this is not going to bode well for Kerry. It's not. His time was up. It's done. He's not going to be able to win. President Trump would just clobber him. So I don't even know what they're thinking. I mean, Joe Biden is obviously a much better choice.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Jesse, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, it's not the first time Kerry has been accused of being a traitor. Trump would devour John Kerry. I could see it now: "Boring, Bike-Riding John, the Iran deal John..."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Like a burger with Heinz ketchup on it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wind surfing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: "... married for money, Windsurfing Johnny, the plastic senator from Massachusetts. You know, smeared Vietnam soldiers." He would wipe the floor with him. It wouldn't even be close.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You think so?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know so.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I don't think he stuttered.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So Greg, the other part of this is, you know, that clearly, the Trump administration is holding money back from the Palestinians. They've recognized Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. These are things that the Palestinians and a lot of their allies overseas are saying, "Well, what happened to the U.S. as a fair partner, potentially negotiating a long- standing peace deal?"

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That is -- that is actually what he's talking about. It is fair, and it's disgusting what Kerry did, going over there, undermining the president. It's just wrong.

utterances.speaker: Watching John Kerry run. Think about that. It's like a praying mantis skipping. He is -- he is just garstoric (ph) totem pole without the flexibility. I'd call him a driftwood sculpture, but I've already said that once. And you're right
utterances.utterance: Trump is going to treat him like a bath mat; he's going to wipe his feet on his head.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I do wonder if the Palestinians floated that story and that it's not true.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's not been confirmed.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The Kerry piece. It doesn't sound like something that he would do. And so it -- that could be fake news.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, the Palestinians have also refused to meet with...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, I mean...

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: ... Vice President Pence, which upsets President Trump, because Pence went over there to meet with them.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What I'm saying is fake would be the -- that Kerry said to the Palestinians, "Just hold on. He's not going to be president in a year."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, we haven't confirmed.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I wouldn't -- I wouldn't put it past the Palestinians to make that up in order to get attention.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, remember, you've got a lot of angles here. So anyway, did you have a sandwich for lunch today?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You may be destroying the planet, you, according to some global warming alarmists. Anyway, Kimberly will have more next.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. I am very upset. Two of my favorite things, sandwiches and meat, they're coming under attack. Did you hear, environmentalists are putting for a tax on meat, claiming hamburgers, steaks and other delicious delectables are harmful to the environment. And then there are the sandwich police. You know them. Some scientists claim that they're bad for the planet, too, for all kinds of reasons because of ingredients and packaging. So Dana, can you believe this ridiculousness?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No. I saw there's going to be mandatory roof gardens in Denver.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, you can do -- you should go do "Watters' World" out there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Mandatory?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Mandatory roof gardens in Denver.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Like greening the city and...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think the environmentalists should take a page out of the Donald Trump playbook and try to figure out a way to make the art of the deal. There are a lot of conservatives -- it's a surprising number to me -- that support the idea of a carbon tax.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Boo.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And if they were to do that, then all of these other little things that they want to do that would hurt the things people are trying to sell for people to eat would go away.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Boo.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right, Greg, what do you make of this? I mean, you're a carnivore.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I am, and I'm going to break this story. I sent it around to you guys. No response. About how selling -- giving away at straws at restaurants, you can go to jail.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You guys don't even read the stuff I send you.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Just so you know, nobody got that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We weren't on the e-mail.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, never mind.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: What is wrong with you? No one got it. You didn't send it to us.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Let's talk about some evolutionary science here. Meat made us the king of all beasts, because there's no other way to get protein-rich nutrients than meat. You can say, "Oh, eat spinach." You're going to have to rent a U-Haul to eat all the spinach that you get from a steak. It's a fact. The reason why we have these brains is because we ate so much meat for 200,000 years. So if you think about PETA and environmentalist groups, veganism, they're all able to exist now in 2018 because of the meat eaters of the past who built this amazing civilization that allows unfocused adults to chase their fringe causes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK, so I don't get this. It's so crazy, Jesse. So they're saying that this causes global warming, all of it. I mean, it's unbelievable to me. What about the children, Jesse? Eat sandwiches.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You've got to do it for the kids. The Lunchables. Don't touch the Lunchables.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Americans will tolerate crazy left-wing environmental wackos to a certain extent. When they tell us we can't use the aerosol deodorant, we say, "Fine." When they say we have to put the bottles in a different bin and recycle.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We say OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We say OK. But you know what? Then they come after the meat and they come at -- no.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We're drawing the red line on the meat?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We're drawing the headline at the hamburgers and the hot dogs. They've already talked about we can't drive certain cars. We don't like that. They've also said something about sodas. I think they don't like drinking big gulp sodas any more here in Manhattan. So it's gotten to the point where it's become too ridiculous, and they're just climbing (ph) themselves.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I had two hot dogs today. No bun.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Eww, no bun?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Atkins? Atkins?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, I didn't have any. No, I didn't have any edible buns. There was nothing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Did you eat it with a knife and fork, or did you just...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I cut it up and used a little spicy mustard.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Did you have any pepperoni for a quesadilla?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I also had pepperoni today, too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's good. You know what? You're going to be doing this in ten years when you're my age, pal. No more bread. You're going to be eating nothing but meat.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What's wrong with brad?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Carbohydrates, sugar make you fat. There's no question about that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm not so sure about that.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Also -- then what kind of diet are you on now?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You should see my "One More Thing."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm just saying.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: What happened over the holidays?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know in New York, they don't eat bread? They put toxins in their head.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right. Juan, what do you have to say about this?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what surprised me?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: This is coming from your folks.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what? Well, let me just speak -- before I get to that, Kimberly, let me just say what is surprising the most was they say the worst sandwich, the one that has the worst, most impact on the environment, is a breakfast sandwich with sausage, bacon and eggs.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yum.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: They said it's the equivalent of driving 12 miles if you just eat one.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, then I drove all over the country this morning, because I had...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Did you eat two?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I had two bacon, egg and cheese sandwiches.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God, they're so good.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Look at you.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Would you go bacon, egg and cheese over, like, a sausage, egg and cheese?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'd prefer the bacon, egg and cheese.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: With the sausage as a nice little lean patty on there. I'll take the sausage.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes. So it's -- Starbucks has a lean one.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's worse than your private plane now in terms of the cost.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: If you put the bread on those sandwiches, what you're eating is ten times better than breakfast cereals, granola, yogurt. A big dish of yogurt, a big dish of yogurt from Chobani or wherever is like having ice cream for breakfast. But if you have -- if you have lean meat, if you have protein. An egg, yellow, the yolk, not whites. Enough of this egg white crap.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I'm with you. I eat the whole thing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Eat the damn yolk. The yolk is the most important thing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You had yolk.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm pro-yolk.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: By the way, it's tasty. It's beautiful. It goes down well.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You can get this nowhere else on cable news.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what? You know what? I have one last thing to say.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I had a hard-boiled egg too. I ate the yellow one. Lean over.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Hey, take it easy. A man eater. But I will say, I was stunned to realize it's that Americans eat two times as much meat as anybody else in the world.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, that's because we win all the world wars, Juan.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We've got to go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We're undefeated.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: How about...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Don't fix what's not broken.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I agree. Well, you know, there's more food stuff coming up. You know what I'm talking about. "One More Thing" next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. It's time for "One More Thing." I go first with this.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.utterance: Greg's Total Bummer News

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "Greg's Total Bummer News." This story will probably be -- it will only be on this show on this network, on any network in America. The announcement that Mark E. Smith from The Fall passed away yesterday at the age of 60. Nobody else cares about this guy. This is the lead singer of The Fall, one of the seminal punk bands, one of the most disagreeable geniuses on the face of the earth. If you haven't heard of him, he's an acquired taste. I urge you to look up his stuff. Go on YouTube. Search "Cruiser's Creek" or "Dr. Buck's Letter." His music is amazing. And he will be missed.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Have you ever played that on the show?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I played -- I just played it today.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You just described yourself. Disagreeable genius, and acquired taste.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you! All right. Rest in peace, Mark Smith, Mark E. Smith, that is. All right. Next up, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, my twin granddaughters love dolls. They're regulars at the American Girl place and own an army of Barbies. Now there's a new generation of dolls, Breaking Barriers. Mattel released photos of new dolls modeled after actresses Oprah Winfrey, Reese Witherspoon and Mindy Kaling who star in Disney's film adaptation of the beloved children's book, "A Wrinkle in Time." Fans on social media are gushing over the dolls, and the film's director, Ava Duvernay, noted how special it is to see a diverse representation of powerful women in Barbies. So now I'm rooting for Kimberly and Dana as dolls.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I would love to be a doll.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Transition.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Thank you so much. It's time for "Kimberly's Food Court." Da, da-da, daa, neer, neer-neer. OK. Taco Bell lovers, identify yourself. Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Me!

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes. Jesse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Although my intestines disagree.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: The next time you place an order, you may want to just ask, do you want fries with that? Because we've got these super delicious Taco Bell cheesy fries.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Look at that.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: They come with this, like, nacho cheese. Jess, what do you think? You've been eating a lot of it. It's got a little spicy kick to it. Do you love it?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: They have Mexican seasoning on it. And I mean, I think it's, like, a bargain, because you get the side of cheese.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Taco Bell is the Edison lab of food.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It's so good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They invent.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Thank you so much. One dollar.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: One dollar.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow, that's good. Like a bargain.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You can get all of this.
